input_text:
[{"role": "user", "content": "You are part of a group with 3 members (you and two randomly selected other participants). Each group has the possibility to conduct a project, call project A. If you do not conduct the project each group member receives a payoff of 0 euro for the project. If your group conducts project A, then each group member receives his or her private valuation for the project as payment. The private valuation of project A can be different for each member of your group. If your group decides not to conduct project A, all group members receive a payoff of zero. The individual participants can not identify the other group members. Thus, you will not know which other participants are in your group. The decision has two parts. In the first part, each group picks a decision rule to decide on implementing project A or not. In the second part, your group applies the chosen rule to decide on project A. You will be informed about your private valuation for project A after part one. We will now explain to you the two different parts of each round as well as the possible decision rules in detail. 

In part one you have the choice between two different decision rules, which will be used to determine whether project A is implemented or not, in part two. Each of the three group members suggests one of the two available rules for part two of this round. A computer randomly picks one of these suggestions as group rule. This decision rule determines how in part 2 the question whether project A is implemented or not is resolved. Each group member has the same chance for his or her suggestion to be selected. Please note that the decision rule is important, because dependent on the decision rule the implementation of project A is easier or more difficult. The different rules are explained below.

In part 2 the selected decision rule is used to determine whether project A is implemented or not. The group decision arises directly from the decisions of all group members in part 2. The decision is announced and each participants is informed about his or her payment.

In case project A is implemented all group members receive a payment depended on their project valuations. This means, if your valuation for project A is positive, you benefit from the implementation of project A, and when your valuation for project A is negative, then you have to pay if the project is implemented. You learn your valuation after part 1. Therefore you do not know your valuation when you decide between the different decision rules in part 1, but you know your valuation in part 2 when you decide about the implementation of project A according to the selected decision rule. If your group does not implement project A, each group member receives 0 euro, meaning you neither gain nor lose anything, independently of your valuation for project A



 the valuation of each group member can be -3 euro, -1 euro, +1 eurp, +3 euro. All values are equally likely 
 Rule 1 = Simple majority vote (SM): At least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A. In part II all group members vote either for or against the implementation of project A. At least 2 group members have to vote for the implementation, otherwise project A is not implemented.

 Rule 2 = The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): Whether project A is implemented or not depends on the stated valuations of all group members. With this decision rule in part 2 each group member states his or her valuation for the project. If the sum of all statements is larger than 0, then project A is implemented. If the sum is smaller, the project is not implemented. Each participant has to state a possible valuation. He or she can state his or her true valuation, but also any other possible valuation. The calculation of the sum only depends on the stated valuations true valuations are not taken into account. 

Additionally to the payments from an implementation of project A there are transfer payments between the group members with this decision rule. The height of transfer payments depends on the stated valuation and the stated valuations of the other group members. Below in the table you can see which transfers you receive / pay depended on the stated valuations, with the stated valuations of the others in the top row, and your stated valuations in the first column.

Please note: A transfer payment is independent of your true valuation and the implementation of project A. You can also receive or pay a transfer if project A is not implemented.

Transfers are chosen such that your expected payoff is maximized if you state your true valuation and also the other group members state their true valuation. The table states the transfers for all possible combinations. The first column contains your statement and the respective columns to the right list the transfers dependent on the statements of the other group members. However, you do not know the valuations or stated valuations of the other members. 

;3,3;1,3;-1,3;-1,1;-1,-1;3,-3;1,-3;-1,-3;1,1;-3,-3
3;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;-0.25;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;0
1;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0.25
-1;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0.25
-3;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;-0.25;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;0 Based on this explanation which decision rule would you choose? 

Letâ€™s think step by step before answering 

Conclude with: "chosen_rule={abbreviation of chosen rule}"

"}, {"role": "system", "content": "First, let's analyze the two decision rules:

1. Simple majority vote (SM): This rule requires at least two group members to vote for the implementation of project A. It is a straightforward and easy rule to follow, as it only requires a majority decision.

2. The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): This rule takes into account the stated valuations of all group members. The implementation of project A depends on the sum of all stated valuations, disregarding true valuations. This rule involves transfer payments between group members based on their stated valuations.

Considering the simplicity and fairness of the rules, I would choose rule 1 (Simple majority vote) as it is easier to understand and implement, and it does not involve complex calculations or transfers between group members.

Chosen_rule=SM"}]
explanation_mechanism:
First, let's analyze the two decision rules:

1. Simple majority vote (SM): This rule requires at least two group members to vote for the implementation of project A. It is a straightforward and easy rule to follow, as it only requires a majority decision.

2. The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): This rule takes into account the stated valuations of all group members. The implementation of project A depends on the sum of all stated valuations, disregarding true valuations. This rule involves transfer payments between group members based on their stated valuations.

Considering the simplicity and fairness of the rules, I would choose rule 1 (Simple majority vote) as it is easier to understand and implement, and it does not involve complex calculations or transfers between group members.

Chosen_rule=SM
explanation_phase_2:
Given that my private valuation is negative (-3 euro) and the decision rule is SM (Simple Majority Vote), where at least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A, I would vote against the implementation of project A. 

vote=0

1. Simple Majority Vote (SM): In order for project A to be implemented, at least two group members must vote for it. This rule could potentially lead to a deadlock if all group members have different valuations for the project.

2. Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): Project A will be implemented if the sum of all stated valuations is greater than 0. This rule takes into account the valuations of all group members and includes transfer payments based on the stated valuations.

Given the potential for deadlock with the Simple Majority Vote rule, it may be more advantageous to choose the Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV) rule. This rule allows for a more nuanced decision-making process that considers all valuations and includes transfer payments to optimize expected payoffs.

Therefore, based on the potential outcomes and considerations, I would choose:

chosen_rule=AGV

To maximize my expected payoff, I would state my true valuation of +1 euro.

This decision rule determines how in part 2 the question whether project A is implemented or not is resolved. Each group member has the same chance for his or her suggestion to be selected. Please note that the decision rule is important, because dependent on the decision rule the implementation of project A is easier or more difficult. The different rules are explained below.

In part 2 the selected decision rule is used to determine whether project A is implemented or not. The group decision arises directly from the decisions of all group members in part 2. The decision is announced and each participants is informed about his or her payment.

 the valuation of each group member can be -3 euro, -1 euro, +1 eurp, +3 euro. All values are equally likely 
 Rule 1 = Flipping a random coin (RAND): The decision for or against implementation of project A depends on the result of a coin flip. There is not voting. [{"role": "user", "content": "You are part of a group with 3 members (you and two randomly selected other participants). Each group has the possibility to conduct a project, call project A. If you do not conduct the project each group member receives a payoff of 0 euro for the project. If your group conducts project A, then each group member receives his or her private valuation for the project as payment. The private valuation of project A can be different for each member of your group. If your group decides not to conduct project A, all group members receive a payoff of zero. The individual participants can not identify the other group members. Thus, you will not know which other participants are in your group. The decision has two parts. In the first part, each group picks a decision rule to decide on implementing project A or not. In the second part, your group applies the chosen rule to decide on project A. You will be informed about your private valuation for project A after part one. We will now explain to you the two different parts of each round as well as the possible decision rules in detail. 

In part one you have the choice between two different decision rules, which will be used to determine whether project A is implemented or not, in part two. Each of the three group members suggests one of the two available rules for part two of this round. A computer randomly picks one of these suggestions as group rule. This decision rule determines how in part 2 the question whether project A is implemented or not is resolved. Each group member has the same chance for his or her suggestion to be selected. Please note that the decision rule is important, because dependent on the decision rule the implementation of project A is easier or more difficult. The different rules are explained below.

In part 2 the selected decision rule is used to determine whether project A is implemented or not. The group decision arises directly from the decisions of all group members in part 2. The decision is announced and each participants is informed about his or her payment.

In case project A is implemented all group members receive a payment depended on their project valuations. This means, if your valuation for project A is positive, you benefit from the implementation of project A, and when your valuation for project A is negative, then you have to pay if the project is implemented. You learn your valuation after part 1. Therefore you do not know your valuation when you decide between the different decision rules in part 1, but you know your valuation in part 2 when you decide about the implementation of project A according to the selected decision rule. If your group does not implement project A, each group member receives 0 euro, meaning you neither gain nor lose anything, independently of your valuation for project A



 the valuation of each group member can be -3 euro, -1 euro, +1 euro, +7 euro. All values are equally likely 
 Rule 1 = Simple majority vote (SM): At least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A. In part II all group members vote either for or against the implementation of project A. At least 2 group members have to vote for the implementation, otherwise project A is not implemented.

 Rule 2 = The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): Whether project A is implemented or not depends on the stated valuations of all group members. With this decision rule in part 2 each group member states his or her valuation for the project. If the sum of all statements is larger than 0, then project A is implemented. If the sum is smaller, the project is not implemented. Each participant has to state a possible valuation. He or she can state his or her true valuation, but also any other possible valuation. The calculation of the sum only depends on the stated valuations true valuations are not taken into account. 

Additionally to the payments from an implementation of project A there are transfer payments between the group members with this decision rule. Transfers are chosen such that your expected payoff is maximized if you state your true valuation and also the other group members state their true valuation. If you do not conduct the project each group member receives a payoff of 0 euro for the project. If your group conducts project A, then each group member receives his or her private valuation for the project as payment. The private valuation of project A can be different for each member of your group. If your group decides not to conduct project A, all group members receive a payoff of zero. The individual participants can not identify the other group members. Thus, you will not know which other participants are in your group. The decision has two parts. In the first part, each group picks a decision rule to decide on implementing project A or not. In the second part, your group applies the chosen rule to decide on project A. You will be informed about your private valuation for project A after part one. We will now explain to you the two different parts of each round as well as the possible decision rules in detail. 

In part one you have the choice between two different decision rules, which will be used to determine whether project A is implemented or not, in part two. Each of the three group members suggests one of the two available rules for part two of this round. A computer randomly picks one of these suggestions as group rule. This decision rule determines how in part 2 the question whether project A is implemented or not is resolved. Each group member has the same chance for his or her suggestion to be selected. Please note that the decision rule is important, because dependent on the decision rule the implementation of project A is easier or more difficult. The different rules are explained below.

In part 2 the selected decision rule is used to determine whether project A is implemented or not. The group decision arises directly from the decisions of all group members in part 2. The decision is announced and each participants is informed about his or her payment.

In case project A is implemented all group members receive a payment depended on their project valuations. This means, if your valuation for project A is positive, you benefit from the implementation of project A, and when your valuation for project A is negative, then you have to pay if the project is implemented. You learn your valuation after part 1. Therefore you do not know your valuation when you decide between the different decision rules in part 1, but you know your valuation in part 2 when you decide about the implementation of project A according to the selected decision rule. If your group does not implement project A, each group member receives 0 euro, meaning you neither gain nor lose anything, independently of your valuation for project A



 the valuation of each group member can be -7 euro, -1 euro, +1 euro, +3 euro. All values are equally likely 
 Rule 1 = Simple majority vote (SM): At least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A. In part II all group members vote either for or against the implementation of project A. At least 2 group members have to vote for the implementation, otherwise project A is not implemented.

 Rule 2 = The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): Whether project A is implemented or not depends on the stated valuations of all group members. With this decision rule in part 2 each group member states his or her valuation for the project. If the sum of all statements is larger than 0, then project A is implemented. If the sum is smaller, the project is not implemented. Each participant has to state a possible valuation. He or she can state his or her true valuation, but also any other possible valuation. The calculation of the sum only depends on the stated valuations true valuations are not taken into account. 

Additionally to the payments from an implementation of project A there are transfer payments between the group members with this decision rule. The height of transfer payments depends on the stated valuation and the stated valuations of the other group members. Below in the table you can see which transfers you receive / pay depended on the stated valuations, with the stated valuations of the others in the top row, and your stated valuations in the first column.

Please note: A transfer payment is independent of your true valuation and the implementation of project A. You can also receive or pay a transfer if project A is not implemented.

Transfers are chosen such that your expected payoff is maximized if you state your true valuation and also the other group members state their true valuation. The table states the transfers for all possible combinations. The first column contains your statement and the respective columns to the right list the transfers dependent on the statements of the other group members. However, you do not know the valuations or stated valuations of the other members. 

;3,3;1,3;-1,3;-1,1;-1,-1;3,-3;1,-3;-1,-3;1,1;-3,-3
3;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;-0.25;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;0
1;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0.25
-1;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0;0.25;0.125;0.125;0;0.25
-3;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;-0.25;0;-0.125;-0.125;-0.25;0 Based on this explanation which decision rule would you choose? 

Letâ€™s think step by step before answering 

Conclude with: "chosen_rule={abbreviation of chosen rule}"

"}, {"role": "system", "content": "First, we need to consider the different decision rules available: Simple majority vote (SM) and Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV). 

If we choose the Simple majority vote (SM) rule, at least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A in order for it to be implemented. This means that if two out of the three group members have a positive valuation for the project, they can ensure its implementation. 

On the other hand, if we choose the Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV) rule, the implementation of project A depends on the stated valuations of all group members. This rule involves transfer payments between group members based on their stated valuations, regardless of the true valuations. 

Considering the uncertainty of not knowing the other group members' valuations, and the complexity of the AGV rule with transfer payments, it might be safer to choose the Simple majority vote (SM) rule. This rule simplifies the decision-making process and relies on a straightforward majority vote for implementation.

Therefore, based on these considerations, I would choose the Simple majority vote (SM) rule.

Conclude with: "chosen_rule=SM""}]
explanation_mechanism:
First, we need to consider the different decision rules available: Simple majority vote (SM) and Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV). 

If we choose the Simple majority vote (SM) rule, at least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A in order for it to be implemented. This means that if two out of the three group members have a positive valuation for the project, they can ensure its implementation. 

On the other hand, if we choose the Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV) rule, the implementation of project A depends on the stated valuations of all group members. This rule involves transfer payments between group members based on their stated valuations, regardless of the true valuations. 

Considering the uncertainty of not knowing the other group members' valuations, and the complexity of the AGV rule with transfer payments, it might be safer to choose the Simple majority vote (SM) rule. This rule simplifies the decision-making process and relies on a straightforward majority vote for implementation.

Therefore, based on these considerations, I would choose the Simple majority vote (SM) rule.

Conclude with: "chosen_rule=SM"
explanation_phase_2:
Since my private valuation is negative, I would choose to vote against the implementation of project A in this case. 
vote=0

This means, if your valuation for project A is positive, you benefit from the implementation of project A, and when your valuation for project A is negative, then you have to pay if the project is implemented. [{"role": "user", "content": "You are part of a group with 3 members (you and two randomly selected other participants). Each group has the possibility to conduct a project, call project A. If you do not conduct the project each group member receives a payoff of 0 euro for the project. If your group conducts project A, then each group member receives his or her private valuation for the project as payment. The private valuation of project A can be different for each member of your group. If your group decides not to conduct project A, all group members receive a payoff of zero. The individual participants can not identify the other group members. Thus, you will not know which other participants are in your group. The decision has two parts. In the first part, each group picks a decision rule to decide on implementing project A or not. In the second part, your group applies the chosen rule to decide on project A. You will be informed about your private valuation for project A after part one. We will now explain to you the two different parts of each round as well as the possible decision rules in detail. 

In part one you have the choice between two different decision rules, which will be used to determine whether project A is implemented or not, in part two. Each of the three group members suggests one of the two available rules for part two of this round. A computer randomly picks one of these suggestions as group rule. This decision rule determines how in part 2 the question whether project A is implemented or not is resolved. Each group member has the same chance for his or her suggestion to be selected. Please note that the decision rule is important, because dependent on the decision rule the implementation of project A is easier or more difficult. The different rules are explained below.

In part 2 the selected decision rule is used to determine whether project A is implemented or not. The group decision arises directly from the decisions of all group members in part 2. The decision is announced and each participants is informed about his or her payment.

In case project A is implemented all group members receive a payment depended on their project valuations. This means, if your valuation for project A is positive, you benefit from the implementation of project A, and when your valuation for project A is negative, then you have to pay if the project is implemented. You learn your valuation after part 1. Therefore you do not know your valuation when you decide between the different decision rules in part 1, but you know your valuation in part 2 when you decide about the implementation of project A according to the selected decision rule. If your group does not implement project A, each group member receives 0 euro, meaning you neither gain nor lose anything, independently of your valuation for project A



 the valuation of each group member can be -7 euro, -1 euro, +1 euro, +3 euro. All values are equally likely 
 Rule 1 = Simple majority vote (SM): At least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A. In part II all group members vote either for or against the implementation of project A. At least 2 group members have to vote for the implementation, otherwise project A is not implemented.

 Rule 2 = The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): Whether project A is implemented or not depends on the stated valuations of all group members. With this decision rule in part 2 each group member states his or her valuation for the project. If the sum of all statements is larger than 0, then project A is implemented. If the sum is smaller, the project is not implemented. Each participant has to state a possible valuation. He or she can state his or her true valuation, but also any other possible valuation. The calculation of the sum only depends on the stated valuations true valuations are not taken into account. 

Additionally to the payments from an implementation of project A there are transfer payments between the group members with this decision rule. The height of transfer payments depends on the stated valuation and the stated valuations of the other group members. Below in the table you can see which transfers you receive / pay depended on the stated valuations, with the stated valuations of the others in the top row, and your stated valuations in the first column.

Please note: A transfer payment is independent of your true valuation and the implementation of project A. You can also receive or pay a transfer if project A is not implemented.

Transfers are chosen such that your expected payoff is maximized if you state your true valuation and also the other group members state their true valuation. The table states the transfers for all possible combinations. The first column contains your statement and the respective columns to the right list the transfers dependent on the statements of the other group members. However, you do not know the valuations or stated valuations of the other members.

Under the Simple Majority Vote rule, at least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A. This means that if one member values the project positively, they could potentially sway the decision in favor of implementation. 

On the other hand, under the AGV rule, the decision to implement project A is based on the sum of all stated valuations. This rule involves transfer payments between group members, and the height of these payments depends on the stated valuations of all members.

Given that the valuations of each group member can be -7 euro, -1 euro, +1 euro, +3 euro, and all values are equally likely, the AGV rule seems more complex but potentially more beneficial if all group members state their true valuations.

Chosen_rule=AGV"}]

Chosen_rule=AGV

If your group does not implement project A, each group member receives 0 euro, meaning you neither gain nor lose anything, independently of your valuation for project A



 the valuation of each group member can be -3 euro, -2 euro, -1 euro, +7 euro. All values are equally likely 
 Rule 1 = Simple majority vote (SM): At least two group members have to vote for the implementation of project A. In part II all group members vote either for or against the implementation of project A. At least 2 group members have to vote for the implementation, otherwise project A is not implemented.

 Rule 2 = The theoretical optimal Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV): Whether project A is implemented or not depends on the stated valuations of all group members. With this decision rule in part 2 each group member states his or her valuation for the project. If the sum of all statements is larger than 0, then project A is implemented. If the sum is smaller, the project is not implemented. Each participant has to state a possible valuation. He or she can state his or her true valuation, but also any other possible valuation. The calculation of the sum only depends on the stated valuations true valuations are not taken into account. 

Additionally to the payments from an implementation of project A there are transfer payments between the group members with this decision rule. The height of transfer payments depends on the stated valuation and the stated valuations of the other group members. Below in the table you can see which transfers you receive / pay depended on the stated valuations, with the stated valuations of the others in the top row, and your stated valuations in the first column.

Please note: A transfer payment is independent of your true valuation and the implementation of project A. You can also receive or pay a transfer if project A is not implemented.

Transfers are chosen such that your expected payoff is maximized if you state your true valuation and also the other group members state their true valuation. The table states the transfers for all possible combinations. The first column contains your statement and the respective columns to the right list the transfers dependent on the statements of the other group members. However, you do not know the valuations or stated valuations of the other members.

First, let's consider the possible outcomes under each decision rule. 

Under the Simple Majority vote (SM) rule, at least two group members must vote for the implementation of project A. This means that if at least one member has a positive valuation for the project, there is a chance that project A will be implemented.

Under the Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV) rule, the decision to implement project A is based on the sum of all stated valuations. This rule takes into account the stated valuations of all group members, including the possibility of transfer payments. 

Given that the valuation of each group member can be -3 euro, -2 euro, -1 euro, or +7 euro, it seems that the AGV rule may be more beneficial in maximizing expected payoff, as it considers all valuations and allows for potential transfer payments.

Therefore, I would choose the Arrow-d'Aspremont-Gerard-Varet (AGV) rule.
